Getting started

Welcome to our research group! We’re thrilled to have you with us and are committed to ensuring your experience here is enriching and enjoyable. During your time with us, we hope you’ll delve deeply into brain stimulation applications, clinical neuroscience, and mental health care. You’ll have the opportunity to develop valuable skills in data analysis, writing, and presenting. We also encourage you to build connections and friendships within the group, and, most importantly, have a lot of fun along the way.

Welcome aboard!

Lucia, Gerrit & Frank

Who is who

Group lead

Our group is led by Lucia Bulubas, Gerrit Burkhardt and Frank Padberg.

  • Frank has founded the research group almost two decades ago. He is a consultant psychiatrist and in charge of HR at our Department. Besides brain stimulation, he also is co-lead of the psychotherapy research group and is in charge of the ward B1b which offers a specialized psychotherapy program for the treatment of patients with chronic depression (CBASP).
  • Gerrit has joined the group as a study doctor in 2019. He now is a junior consultant psychiatrist at our department. Within our group he is responsible for conducting randomized controlled treatment trials using optimized study designs (Patient-centered Translational Trials [PACTT] unit). He also specializes on new approaches for depression measurement like digital phenotyping, treatment stratification and personalization, and meta-analytic research.
  • Lucia has joined the group in 20XX. She is in charge of our clinical brain stimulation service (Stimulationsambulanz), in which we offer in- and out-patient treatment with rTMS and tDCS for patients with depression and schizophrenia. She also specializes on MR-informed neurostimulation approaches with the goal to optimized treatment outcomes via individualized dosage parameters. Moreover, she is currently on of the speakers of the Early Career Scientists of the DZPG for the Munich-Augsburg site.

For our projects, we closely cooperate with Daniel Keeser who leads the research group Neuromodulation And Multimodal NeuroImaging and is on the executive board of the Neuroimaging Core Unit Munich (NICUM).

Full-time members

  • Beate Dornheim is our long-year medical technical assistant. She is a very experienced TMS and tDCS operator and will likely be the person teaching you how things work in our brain stimulation service. She attends to several administrative tasks, like patient scheduling, supplies, and accounting.
  • Esther Dechantsreiter is a psychotherapist and doctoral student who is responsible for coordinating treatment referrals and requests from inside and outside our hospital.
  • Jonas Björklund is currently the main study doctor within our group. He is responsible for patient recruitment and medical supervision for our clinical trials.

Current PhD students

  • Miaoxi Chen

Current MD students

  • Kristin Hagenah
  • Marlen Becher
  • Juna Bizhga
  • Katharina von Wartensleben
  • Barbara Huber

Getting around the lab

Our lab is situated at the Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy, LMU University Hospital, Nußbaumstr. 7, 80336 München.

  • Main Workspace: The primary working area for core lab members is in the “Altbau” (Building A), 1st floor, room A1.45. Due to the limited availability of space, we encourage collaboration in managing the workspace. Please coordinate with existing lab members to ensure you are appropriately set up.
  • Study Coordination Office: Adjacent to the main workspace is the study coordination office (A1.46), primarily used for study visits.
  • Brain Stimulation Treatment and Experiment Rooms: These are located on the ground floor (Rooms A…, A…). Room availability and booking are managed via an Outlook calendar.
  • Frank’s Office: Frank’s office is located on the 4th floor of the building.
  • fMRI Scanner: The fMRI scanner is housed in the NICUM on the ground floor.

Housekeeping

  • Due to the presence of sensitive patient data, all rooms must remain locked at all times. You can obtain access through either a group transponder, available to group members at the main reception (“Pforte”), or if you plan to work with us for a year or more, you may request a personal transponder following approval.
  • Please take a moment to introduce yourself to the reception team (“Pförtner”). They are usually very helpful, well-informed about the department’s organizational matters, and appreciate knowing who passes by each day.
  • Please ensure that windows are closed, and doors are locked when leaving any office space.
  • You are welcome to use the lab refrigerator, sink, and dishware. However, please ensure you also contribute to cleaning up, including washing any used items, and be mindful not to leave food in the fridge for too long…

Wifi

Although Wi-Fi reception in the old building can be inconsistent, you should generally be able to connect to either Eduroam or Bayern Wlan.

Lab communication

Our primary mode of daily communication is via email. Additionally, we have a non-mandatory, informal WhatsApp group that you are welcome to join. However, please check with other lab members before contacting them on their personal numbers for work-related matters and be mindful of their privacy.

Getting started with your research career

Setting up your (online) research profile

  • Make sure to register for an Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID). Your ORCID is an unique and persistent identifier that you yourself connect with your professional (scientific) information. This helps to recognize all your work, even if e.g., you change your name, one of your coauthors misspells it, or you move on to a new institution. Getting an ORCID is free and quick and meanwhile, several platforms, from grant application to manuscript submission and beyond, allow you to use your ORCID to log into their system. Note however, that this is a self-maintained identifier. It thus is only as up-to-date as you keep it.
  • Think about setting up a profile on ResearchGate which is a European commercial socialnetworking site for scientists and researchers to share papers, ask and answer questions, and find collaborators.

Keeping up with the literature

With the constant stream of new research being published, it can be challenging to stay up-to-date. Here are some effective strategies to help you keep pace:

  • Use an RSS feed or subscribe to journal table of contents to keep up on the latest work.
  • Make sure to get alerts for preprints, too (e.g., neuroscience-tagged papers on bioRxiv).
  • Keep up with the latest research by doing periodic searches on Google Scholar or Pubmed, and sorting the results by date. Browse article titles for relevant ones, read the abstract to see how relevant it is, and read the paper in full if it is important for your work or if you find it interesting.
  • You should also make a Google Scholar profile, and Google will alert you when relevant research is published, given your publications and the papers you cite, and will also alert you when someone cites you.
  • Feel free to share papers with other lab members (e.g. using our WhatsApp group)
  • Make sure to keep track of all the great ideas you have as you read! E.g. by using something like OneNote/Notes to organize your thoughts and questions.
  • Organizing your references and creating bibliographies with a citation management tool like Zotero, which is free and has a lot of useful features. You can get started with Zotero by checking out this introductory course offered by the LMU Open Science Center.
  • If a publication is hidden behind a paywall

    • check if you have access via the LMU university library

    • contact the authors on ResearchGate and request the manuscript

    • be aware that there are other ways to access publications, which we won’t list here…
